1.0 SECTION ONE ? EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1 Introduction
The following executive summary outlines the key components of the Risk Management Program for the ammonium hydroxide, here after known as aqueous ammonia storage and handling system associated with the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system at El Segundo Generating Station.
1.2 Background
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is submitted on behalf of the El Segundo Generating Station pursuant to the requirements contained in the Clean Air Act 112(r) and its regulations found in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  The CalARP statue is Article 2 of Chapter 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code and those regulations found in Title 19 of the California Code of Regulations (CCR), Chapter 4.5 beginning with 2735.1 through 2785.1. The local administering agency (AA) oversees the development of the RMP.The scope of this RMP is based on discussions with the Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA), the City of El Segundo Fire Department, to ensure that all issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements.  The aqueous ammonium process is the only chemical that triggers the RMP/CalARP requirements as previously agreed to by the CUPA. In the initial RMP submittal it was determined that this process was covered by Program 2 requirements.  
El Segundo Generating Station, located in El Segundo, California, is an electric generating station consisting of two operating units, Units 3 and 4 each rated at 335 megawatts (MW).  These units are capable of combusting either fuel oil or natural gas.  SCR technology was installed on Unit 4 in 1994 and in June  2001 on Unit 3 to control emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx).  The initial RMP was updated in September of 2001 to incorporate changes related to the addition of the Unit 3 SCR system.
SCR is a post-combustion flue-gas NOX emission control technology that removes NOX from the flue ga

s downstream from the combustion process.  A reducing agent is used to reduce NOX emissions, primarily nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), by oxidation-reduction reactions in the presence of a catalyst.  The most common reducing agent (reagent) used with SCR is ammonia.  Injection of ammonia into the combustion exhaust stream before the catalyst initiates the reactions and achieves the desired removal of NOx emissions upstream from the stack.  In order to minimize the handling of hazardous materials, the El Segundo Generating Station will use ammonia in the form of aqueous ammonia as the reagent for the SCR reactions. 
The SCR system in use at the El Segundo Generating Station employs ammonia injection to reduce NOx emissions approximately 80 percent from uncontrolled levels.  Aqueous ammonia is classified as a toxic chemical subject to the requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  The aqueous ammonia used is 29.4 weight percent of ammonia in water, [Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) number 7664-41-7].
The aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at El Segundo Generating Station is made up of a single underground storage tank, pumps, and piping that terminates at the aqueous ammonia vaporizer skid where the aqueous ammonia is atomized.  The underground storage tank is double-walled with a capacity of 20,000 gallons.  It is equipped with pressure relief valves, leak detectors, temperature and pressure reference level indicators.  The aqueous ammonia storage tank is filled via a vendor?s 6,000-gallon tanker truck with deliveries scheduled at regular intervals based upon ammonia consumption.  The aqueous ammonia is pumped through aboveground and belowground 2-inch pipe to the aqueous ammonia vaporizer skids for Boiler Units 3 and 4. Other aqueous ammonia piping include a  3/4-inch line to the chemical treatment system and a 2-inch line that is plugged and seal welded.
All other regulated substances on site are in quanti

ties below state and federal RMP thresholds.   A diagram showing the location of all hazardous materialsfound at the El Segundo Generating Station, including the aqueous ammonia, can be found in the Hazardous Materials and Hazardous Waste Management Plan.
1.3 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
El Segundo Generating Station has had an active hazardous materials management and accident prevention program for many years, and emphasizes safety and good management practices in all its activities. An offsite consequence analysis (OCA) was performed and considered for the implementation of the accident prevention program and the emergency planning. All activities are conducted in accordance with a detailed, Hazardous Materials and Hazardous Waste Management Plan, standard operating procedures, and active participation by management, line and contractor employees.
The accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
?Effective preventive maintenance program
?Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment
?Use of accurate and effective operating procedures 
?Performance of a process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures conducted by those famaliar with the operations and maintenance of the El Segundo Generating Station.
?Implementation of an auditing and inspection program
Other specific steps to prevent accidental ammonia releases include the following:
?The annual training of the operators in the safe handling of aqueous ammonia, with emphasis on the hazardous and toxic properties of the chemical
?The monitoring of tank liquid levels alarm, pressure levels alarm, pressure/vacuum relief valves, and ammonia gas detectors around the storage area

1.4 Regulated Substances Handled
The primary activity of the El Segundo Generating Station is generation of electric power.  The only regulated substance used in an amount triggering the CalARP program is aqueous ammonia (29.4 percent by weight in water), which is us

ed as the reagent for the SCR emission control technology retrofitted on El Segundo Generating Station Units 3 and 4.  The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia to be stored on site will be 20,000 gallons, in one underground storage tank.
1.5 Five-year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases from the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at El Segundo Generating Station in the past 5 years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage  (Statute:  40 CFR 68.42).
1.6 Emergency Response Program
The core elements of the emergency response plan for the El Segundo Generating Station include the following:
?Specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of ammonia
?Procedures to notify local and public agencies including the El Segundo Fire Department, the Office of Emergency Services, and the National Response Center 
?A list of resources for emergency health care
?Information regarding the training of employees on responses to releases
?A list of other federal and state requirements the facility is subject
1.7 Planned Safety Improvement Changes
The What-if revalidation Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) and the seismic evaluation for the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at El Segundo Generating Station, conducted as part of the 5-year update of the RMP, resulted in recommendations to improve the system?s safety.  The following findings and recommendations have been or will soon be implemented:
? Corroded or missing pipe supports have been replaced or added.
? A procedure or design change to detect leakage of the 3/4-inch pipe that supplies the chemical treatment system will be provided.
? Procedural and/or design changes to improve operating reliability of the ammonia vapor scrubber used during aqueous ammonia system maintenance will be implemented.
? Based on the human factors analys

is, additional labeling of components of the aqueous ammonia system will be added or replaced.
? Operating procedures will be updated to reflect changes in the aqueous ammonia unloading operations and consistency between the supplier and owners procedures.
